clinical_study.brief_title: Operative Hemodynamic Optimization Using the Plethysmographic Variability Index During Orthopedic Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Operative Hemodynamic Optimization Using the Plethysmographic Variability Index During Orthopedic Surgery : a Multicentric Prospective Randomized Controlled Study

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether an operative hemodynamic optimization using the plethysmographic variability index during orthopedic surgery could decrease the length of hospital stay and the postoperative morbidity.

primary_outcome.measure: Length of hospital stay after knee or hip arthroplasty
primary_outcome.time_frame: Real length of hospital stay expressed as number of day (maximum 60 days)
primary_outcome.description: Surgeons, blinded to the group allocation, are the postoperative care providers who decide the length of hospital stay.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will be followed for the duration of hospital stay, an expected average of 1 week, until postoperative day 60

secondary_outcome.measure: Theorical length of hospital stay after knee or hip arthroplasty
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Theorical length of hospital stay expressed as number of day (maximum 60 days)
secondary_outcome.description: Evaluation twice per day starting day 3 until up day 60. A check list was used by an independant investigator to define the theorical date of end hospitalisation, from day 3 until day 60

other_outcome.time_frame: Participants will be followed for the duration of hospital stay, an expected average of 1 week, until postoperative day 60

arm_group.description: Standard care using a hemodynamic protocol during general anesthesia

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age > 18 years
- Indication to a knee or hip arthroplasty under general anesthesia
- Sinusal rhythm
Non Inclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant women
- Black skin
- Dialysis
- Cardiac arrythmia
- Sepsis
- Use of another hemodynamic monitoring during surgery
